history.content:
I just took it with Weaver. Weaver is pretty good, its just that the course is incredibly hard also (the hardest imo I have taken yet). I would definetly try to have the easiest possible load for 170 as you can as that is too important a class. 

So I guess I would take 61C this upcoming semester if you think you will be able to get a good enough grade in 70 to declare. (assuming you are CS-intended)

---

Also took it with Weaver, he was definitely less than good. Maybe above responder enjoyed his lecturing style but most of the folks I spoke to did not find his tangents about cryptocurrency, drones, Golang, and esoteric Intel & AMD CPU stuff (out of scope) very useful in a class that already has trouble jamming in a huge amount of content. 

Also he released a project in Golang on the last week of classes which he described, after the fact, as a "Kobiyashi Maru" (read: unsolvable) project. Many people spent slip days in dead week panicking on a project for which it was extremely difficult to get full credit on to the point that it was more worth your time to only complete the first 30% and study for the final instead.

On the other hand, I'm pretty sure Garcia has won multiple awards for teaching and folks seem to love how he's set up CS 10. 

---

Also took it with Weaver and I honestly thought that the class taught me more and developed my skills more than any other class I've taken thus far at Berkeley. Weaver is a pretty entertaining lecturer and cares deeply for the class. That is not to say that the class was not a lot of work. Indeed, it was also more work than any other class I have taken here but I feel as though all that work resulted in my largest academic gains thus far. I honestly was really grateful for the opportunity to learn Go for a project, and he ended up adjusting the grade bins so that they were fair so it's not like it'll wreck your grade more with Weaver.

Quite honestly though, and I actually feel this way about almost all of my classes: the bulk of the learning I do, and everything that is practical that I learn is typically self taught by going through the homeworks, labs and projects, as well as my fellow classmates and TAs on piazza, not in lecture. Whether this is intended or not, I find that almost all of my actual learning does not depend on the lecturer, and instead on the work that the class requires one to do by themselves. The work required by students is pretty standard for a class like 61C, and thus so too are the learning opportunities presented to students on a semesterly basis.

--

Another anon here. No matter what you think about his lecturing style, he was incredibly fair when it came down to grading and he cared. If your grade is all you're concerned about, I really wouldn't worry.

I just took it with Weaver. Weaver is pretty good, its just that the course is incredibly hard also (the hardest imo I have taken yet). I would definetly try to have the easiest possible load for 170 as you can as that is too important a class.

I have not taken CS70 yet but I have already taken CS61A/B and EE16A. My plan was for the fall to take CS70 because it allows me to take more upperdivs in the spring including 170. Should I take CS61C this semester as well with Garcia, or should I put it off with Weaver in the Spring. AKA Weaver vs Garcia how good are they both and is Garcia so good that I should model my schedule around him?
history.subject: Should I take CS61C just because Dan Garcia is teaching it
